definitions.definition: To stop working on a permanent basis, usually because of old age or illness.
definitions.example: Having made a large fortune, he retired.

definitions.definition: (sometimes reflexive) To withdraw; to take away.
To cease use or production of something.
definitions.example: The steamship made thousands of trips over several decades before it was retired by the shipping company.

definitions.definition: To withdraw from circulation, or from the market; to take up and pay.
definitions.example: The central bank retired those notes five years ago.

definitions.definition: To cause to retire; specifically, to designate as no longer qualified for active service; to place on the retired list.
definitions.example: The board retired the old major.

definitions.definition: (of a batsman) To voluntarily stop batting before being dismissed so that the next batsman can bat.
definitions.example: Jones retired in favour of Smith.

definitions.definition: (of a fielder) To make a play which results in a runner or the batter being out, either by means of a put out, fly out or strikeout.
To go back or return; to withdraw or retreat, especially from public view; to go into privacy.
definitions.example: I will retire to the study.

definitions.definition: To retreat from action or danger; to withdraw for safety or pleasure.
definitions.example: The regiment retired from the fray after the Major was killed.

definitions.definition: To recede; to fall or bend back.
definitions.example: Past the point, the shore retires into a sequence of coves.
I will retire for the night.

definitions.definition: To remove or cease to use.
definitions.example: When a hurricane becomes so deadly or destructive that future use would be insensitive, officials may retire the name of the hurricane.

definitions.definition: To fit (a vehicle) with new tires.

definitions.example: I don't really know him well, since he's so shy and retiring.
